description:
ggdgsagggg;
fhf'kgjllj'k''poi;

Been using for foobar for a few years, and it's way more customizable than any other mp3 player I've used. You can create unlimited custom tags, and do all sorts of crazy things with columns and filters to suit your heart's desires. Plus, there's a ton of extensions, so you can probably make it do whatever you want. It's a WINE application which can cause some problems (had to get creative to make it work on a 4k screen) and if you want something that's simple and no fuss, it's probably not for you. But if you want flexibility foobar's the way to go.

The default music player is also good. At least for listening.
You can prefer it if you have a too BIG library of music :-( sadly I don't have that.
summary: Default is Enough for music listening!

description: Has useless junk-formats plugins, but can't read CD-TEXT by default... sheesh
Why does this piece of small app goes with wine installation?

Misleading information. It declares install/download size is 4.9 MB and the foobar2000 folder is 82 MB. Also it seems to require wine and that is not reported as requirement. It also download wine-runtime and 3-stable , cost me 200+MB.
Nvidia Jetson - not supported :(
Bad peace of old Software

I've used foobar2000 for years and it is one of the the best players, probably the best library manager and the only DLNA/UPNP platform that handles CUE sheets properly, so you don't have to "organize" your music collection a certain way or break it into individual track files just to make the player happy.
summary: The only app with the proper CUE sheet support

description: Works just like on windows. I can use all the same plug ins and theme just fine.

If you love voice of foobar2000 on Windows, for me its flat, real, quite soft and no sharp. ...merge to voice of linux, for me its clear, stable and still. 


You will love foobar2000 much more. no on know , you must try

Doing anything in this install of foobar2000 is painfully slow compared to simply installing the regular version in wine without snap, and the program crashes on the first attempt to play a song.

This should be a 5 star review, as I love foobar2000, but I just can't justify it at the moment.

Foobar2000 is flat out the best player in history. The extensibility and plugins make it a beast. Sadly it is and always has been Windows only. Any review on here "wineing" about wine are fools. Obviously it needs wine. Any of the other gripes are simply unfounded period. I've been an audio professional over nearly 30 years and I've always hoping hydrogen audio would port Foobar...even my DAW has been ported to Linux but alas we will need wine for this masterpiece.

Despite the high praise I've found with some versions of Wine it's rock solid, others not so much. Basically every wine update poses a risk. Unless you "bottle" a very specific version for Foobar it's probably best to use something native.

I miss Foobar for a lot of reasons but I make due with Audacious these days. Nothing else has ever filled the gap. I've had years of people suggesting players but they all suck. DeadBeef might be considered close UI wise but it is terrible. Some of the core features are broken or modal windows that negate the point...just problems all over. On top of this every player I've tried to fill the gap over the years lacks support key file formats. Comically Audcaious can play them all where others can't. Not even the uber bloated library players. It's always kind of mind blowing when kitchen sink players like Rhythmbox, Amarok, Clementine, Banshee etc can't. Not even VLC will play midi so...
summary: Best Music Player in History but with catches

description: Works like Windows, I used to listen there when I was Windows user... I've never thought that came here, now... it still working great.
Compact and easy to use. Fully satisfy my needs for playing and sorting more than 10.000 items in my playlists. Big recommendation!
simple, lightweight and usefull. recomend it!

This gives you a basic installation but it's impossible to add music from a hard drive you have mounted. `/media/` shows up blank. I haven't found a way to configure wine under snap apps. Also, some components do not work, e.g. Columns UI (probably one of the most common and useful components).

I had much better luck from just downloading the foobar.exe from the website and running it with wine directly.
summary: It runs, but you're better off just using Wine itself

description: I am a long time user on Windows.
summary: did not start due to priviledge issues.

description: i dont recommend
summary: always scratchs in the middle of what im listening too

description: No network support. Completely useless

As with all Wine related apps the optical player does not work with Foobar. so cannot play/rip a cd. Also, I cannot install the much needed codec-pack so only after some creative installation can I add (for example) FLAC support. Starting Foobar is slow.

Works for me on Kubuntu 20.04 with a 27.000 track library on a removable device. On 24k 96kHz FLACs I noticed some artifacts but this might be unrelated to wine and snap. 
All my configs, playlists and components I copied from my Windows machine without problem.
I went on several hour-long searches to try and find a linux native alternative but there isn't one.
summary: Works like a charm, just like on windows!

that's it really
summary: available on windows, android and linux, awsm

description:
Even after granting it every possible permission, the Foobar2000 snap doesn't work on Ubuntu 20.04. It throws the following error:

$ foobar2000 
0009:err:winediag:nodrv_CreateWindow Application tried to create a window, but no driver could be loaded.
0009:err:winediag:nodrv_CreateWindow The explorer process failed to start.

This is a real pity, as Foobar2000 is the greatest music player, bar none!
No problem installing an dthe playback is exactly what I would have expected from Foobar2000.

foobar2000 is high quality and neat audo player not for Windows only but for Linux too. It sounds extremely well, has useful interface and very flexible configuration potential. The fact that it works via Wine is not the problem at all.
This is my basic audio player in Linux for a long time.
It runs without any problems on Ubuntu 20.04.
summary: One of the best players for Linux

description: Great Player and Converter.

Foobar2000 is great app. I am using it on Windows for more then a decade now, and now I have it installed on Ubuntu. The app have much longer startup time on Linux than on Windows, but the functionality is preaty much the same. Gappless function is very important to me because I listen a lot of cut mixes, like A State Of Trance and similar. I would recommend Foobar.
Love it, the best music player I used

description:
This isn't like foobar2000 on Windows. The install also downloads and installs Wine to run foobar. So why not just do that yourself?
It won't allow you to set your library from another hard drive. So if you have a large music collection on a seperate drive you're out of luck.
This whole thing is what is called 'a cludge'. NOT a solution to running foobar on Linux. Waste of time and disk space.

I installed on ubuntu 20.04 and so far it works as good as in windows. This app was the only reason that I was still using windows with vmware. Clementine is the closest to this but still the interface I never got used to it.

Not only does it not work correctly with newer OS, it also installs a lot of garbage along, which is a pain to get rid of, and won't be uninstalled when you uninstall the software.
Stay away from this.
Runs under wine, so large install if you don't already have wine installed. Should mention it is not a native Linux application.
summary: Why is my wine configuration being updated?

Maybe I am missing something, but it appears that this snap makes impossible to use ALSA output (mandatory to easilly avoid pulseaudio resampling), even thtough winetricks. Could be a 32bit / 64bit prefix problem ?

J'ai peut-etre raté quelque-chose, mais la sortie ALSA (solution aisée pour contourner le resampling de pulseaudio) n'est pas sélectionnable avec ce snap (testé sous ubuntu 20, mint 20, garuda). Je ne suis pas parvenu à l'activer non plus via winetricks. Peut-etre en configurant le snap pour qu'il utilise un préfixe 32 bit ?
